Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2010 01:53PM kcshreve wrote: iacai - I would be worried, too, if I were given news of many nodes being taken.  You are very wise to be asking questions from the start, so you can be aware of what your body is doing.  LE is not automatic. There are some with many nodes removed who never develop LE at all.  There are others with NO nodes removed who develop LE.  This part is kind of a mystery.  The more nodes removed the higher the rates, but you never know where you'll fall with all those statistics. You may be fine.  The best thing to do is to realize that you are indeed at risk and to learn how to care for yourself best.  You can find a certified LE therapist and have a consultation.  Possibly they should do some checking for you, will probably take your measurements.  At this point, you probably have sufficient post-surgical swelling, which can complicate the picture for the next couple weeks.  For now, you can keep your arm elevated just to give it a rest and keep swelling down a bit.  Spend some time reading here, you'll learn a lot. Many who do have LE do not develop it immediately.  For some, it's within weeks, for others it's years later.  Awareness is key.  So, you are doing well to have popped in here!

Posts.Content: May 31, 2010 07:21PM kcshreve wrote: There are a number of women whose LE developed after flying without the precaution of sleeves, even though they were told they were fine. If you are able to get fitted this week, it is a very good idea (takes about a week to get in).  This is a small precaution which may help you avoid the permanent condition of lymphedema. Once it develops, there is no going back.  I had a bmx in Jan, developed LE within 4 weeks.  I was terrified to fly after that, but I did well with sleeves and gauntlets on both arms.  Of course, since I do have LE, I have to wear these sleeves every day.  If you could avoid this, I would highly recommend it.  Unless you are dealing with someone very well versed in LE, the professional will tell you it's no big deal. Most doctors are not trained in this.  A surprisingly high number of us have developed LE after being told it was not possible.  Anyone with breast surgery and/or radiation is at risk to some degree

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2010 08:51PM kcshreve wrote: Hannooti,  i did not have a TRAM, but had a DIEP.  Do you have that option near you?  There is a procedure called a TRAM, one that's a Free-Tram or muscle-sparing TRAM - they all use your abdominal muscles to a degree, with the Free Tram using the least amount.  DEIPs use no muscle, only abdominal vessels and tissue.  All these procedures do result in a much smaller tummy.  The recovery from a DIEP is surprisingly fast - from 4-6 weeks.  I had Csections, and the pain afterward was less with a DIEP than a Csection.  Csections cut into your abdominal muscles, too, so you understand that pain.  You would be glad if you found someone who performs the DIEP procedures and if you could get a consultation with them.  From having had this procedure 6 weeks ago, I can recommend it, if you are already interested in it.

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2010 12:29PM kcshreve wrote: I had a breast MRI, but cannot comment about the axillary nodes.  The good thing with an MRI is that it catches smaller spots sooner.  The bad thing about an MRI is that it catches spots which may be entirely normal and is not able to differentiate well.  Each type of imaging sees the areas differently, so it's good to have different methods: mammogram, ultrasound, MRI. I am assuming they are trying to make sure what your options are, given the type and location. I had 2 followup MRI guided biopsies, which placed markers for future tracking. The markers are helpful to pinpoint future growth.  Your diagnosis is so recent, I imagine you're feeling rather upside down right now.  If they find only one location or multiple locations - this will be helpful info in determining how to proceed.

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2011 05:27AM kcshreve wrote: Heaviness and fullness are common symptoms of LE.  That was what I had, which my BS denied as potentially being LE.  A LANA certified therapist was able to be helpful, did a MLD treatment on me, and for the first time in weeks I had some relief, although I did not notice relief for about 3 hours. You may need to discuss this further with your PT - does she do MLD?  Prevention is good, but is not enough if you are having fullness and heaviness.  You got measurements, but what is the treatment plan beyond this?  MLD is the core of treatment, and a sleeve will add to the benefits of MLD.  A sleeve without MLD is only a partial program.  If your PT does not do MLD, find someone soon who does.  Hopefully, that can give you some relief.  And once someone does MLD, you can learn to do it for yourself at home, which gives you more control over your symptoms.

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2010 12:30PM kcshreve wrote: For me, I needed all the info possible.  Short of that, I was going nuts.  THese boards helped me to fill in the gaps.  A counselor is a great idea, and continuing with that makes a ton of sense.  Seeing a counselor will not replace your need for accurate info regarding your condition, though.  Second opinions are essential, further testing asap is essential.  Your biopsy should have given you the type of cancer and it's grade, or if there was no cancer but suspicious tissues, or no cancer at all.  My cancer was not found an a mammo, so I am a big proponent of further testing not waiting.  If you can't get good support and a plan which feels right to you from your current docs, move on.  And move on sooner rather than later.  Some doctors feel they are doing us a service by "wait and see", or doing less testing, or going for the least invasive options from the get go.  Sometimes insurance pressures reinforce this, but it truly is not always in our best interest when we have decisions to make, and when we can't sleep because of all the uncertainties.  Not fair, in my book.  I want to know it all right now, and then let it settle so I have time to make my decisions.  Anyway you look at it, it feels like a whirlwind. By not having sufficient info, for me it would make it worse.

Posts.Content: May 1, 2010 11:30PM kcshreve wrote: I got NO relief until I started MLD with a therapist.  If you can find a good one, they can help you sort through the issues, plus they can assist you in getting some relief, if your discomfort is LE related.  Nodes should not be swollen with LE, since the swelling and extra fluid is between the cells.  It won't show up on an ultrasound, either.  It's fluid which is sitting there, which would normally be picked up by the tiny lymph capillaries, but they are not as good as before, so the fluid just sits there.  A therapist can show you a couple techniques for moving that fluid over to an area which has better functioning capillaries, which then can reduce the swelling discomfort - - IF it is related to LE.

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2010 05:36PM kcshreve wrote: WhatR- for most of us with lymphedema, "fullness" is the common presenting symptom.  If there are lumps or bumps, they can be other issues, or the symptoms of a longer term untreated lymphedema.  About the best thing to do is to get a consultation with a LANA certified LE therapist who can sit with you, see what you see, describe what she sees, do some measurements, and possibly do a very light massage technique to "move" fluids to a different lymph gland area in order to lighten the fullness.  For most of us, our doctors were the least helpful, and the OT/PT trained people have been the most helpful - they simply have more training.  LANA is the primary certifier, and if you can find someone nearby with this certification, you'll be a long ways down the road in getting good help.  Keep asking your questions, we're here to help.

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2012 11:04AM kcshreve wrote: A few years ago we were looking for a small-ish.  We visited several pounds and SPCA's.  We noticed that in the longer term locations (like the SPCA), the workers develop their favorites as they get to know the dogs.  They know which dog is lovable, which one is flexible, which one is playful, which one wants only their way.  There was a lovely black lab who had a strange dew claw (too large for our family).  Everyone adored this guy, who was 2, but visitors were put off my his small deformity.  He continued to live there for several months.  Each time we visited we walked him or played with him for awhile. Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2011 07:30PM kcshreve wrote: I asked the same question to my LE therapist and she told me a story of how it seems our body has a way of "learning", when it comes to LE.  She had a male patient with LE in his leg.  He did not take good care of himself, yet would come in to intensive therapy initially, but would do none of what was requested in between nor afterward.  The LE therapist was sad to think he'd not do well.  While in intensive, he made very good progress, so after several months, he quit.  She did not see him for about 5 years.  Then, he showed up one day, in bad shape, needing more intensive work.  The therapist was surprised that his initial set was something like 4-5 months long.  After such a long break, she wondered how long it would take him this time.  Amazingly, his body responded very well and he was back on track in no time, not needing  anymore therapy after only 4 or 5 weeks, instead of months.  It was her opinion that the body created some kind of new or alternative system initially which was able to be revived and come into play the second go-round.  It's just one case story, I don't have any details.  She had shared it with me because she was so excited herself to see that kind of progress.  So, our efforts do pay off.  Our work makes a difference.  In this man's case, he used his progress to justify quitting.  For me, it motivates me to keep at it, in hopes of diminishing the need or at least giving myself more predictability when it comes to this very unpredictable condition.

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2010 09:08PM kcshreve wrote: cityKitty- recons can be delayed, whether you'd use an implant or a flap, so there is no rush.  It sounds like your primary decision is uni or bilat at this point.  That's so personal.  There are many layers to this decision.  I went bilateral because I knew I'd be a wreck with worrying if I had one remaining breast - that's just me.  Others have gone uni for good reasons, too.  As far as recon goes, it seems that PS offer only procedures they know, which is limiting.  I doubt you are too thin for a flap ,unless  you are super trim.  The docs in New Orleans and Charleston do "stacked" flaps for even thin women with very good results (photos at www.breastcenter.com), so I know it can be done.  Whether or not that interests you is another issue altogether. Again, flaps can be delayed.  However, if you do the mx and flaps at the same time there is a lot less scarring.  Ultimately, you have to get some peace with your decision. Take the time to read and to ponder.  Do you HAVE to keep your 12/1 date?  Can you extend just a few weeks in order to process?  It is my opinion that we are rushed into things, yet looking back an extra couple weeks is probably not a big deal.  You need to find your heart in all this, and to have a little time to come up with a plan which matches you.  I thought I'd go no recon, since I did not want implants.  Flaps seemed scary and risky, especially after meeting with  my local PS who is simply too green yet.  Then, I found the docs in New Orleans, had several talks with their people, did tons more reading, and was able to finally make a decision which matched me.  My end result is very good and, best of all, I was able to get some peace about it before going into surgery.  I wish the same for you.

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2012 02:11AM kcshreve wrote: I have had serious candida issues after antibiotics and have worked out a system which really helps me.  I use Bio-K (unflavored, dairy base) the last day of the antibiotics and continue with it for 2 weeks.  The first day I use a half bottle in the am, then finish it in the pm. After that I use a full bottle in the am and pm for a couple days, then only once per day till I'm done. I also really, really like Renew Life's Ultimate Flora capsules, Critical Care, and take a capsule in the morning as well as the evening for 2 weeks, then taper down to one per day for a couple more weeks.  This combo has done me well.  When I was having my surgeries with lots of antibiotics, I also added CandiGone herbal combo to combat the baddies.  They can all work together.  It is expensive, but I've just had to go for it in order to get around the awful side effects of the antibiotics. For me, nothing else has every knocked it out as well.

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2012 11:20PM kcshreve wrote: ((((Chris)))) I well remember the crazy feeling I had when first working through all the new LE procedures. It was overwhelming and I was often discouraged.  It does get better, but it tends to come and go in severity for many of us.  I have confirmed LE in my right arm, but not my left.  However, my left non-LE arm is often very effected - it just seems to balance itself a bit better, so that's why it's not officially LE on that arm.  I've recently been working with a new therapist who is more aggressive in the lower abdominal drainage, and I've found that to be surprisingly helpful.  Maybe it can help you, too.  In addition to my existing MLD work, he has me working the abdominal area 2 ways - breathing, and massaging.  The breathing starts with a very strong exhale, which includes tight kegels to fully compress and hold.  To inhale, I'm to simply release all tension and allow breath to come in, then fully inhale.  Repeat many times.  The massaging component is done deeply in the triangle between the hip bones and the belly button, as well as over my scar, as I had a DIEP recon with a scar that runs side seam to side seam.  Those deep nodes are the core of our body's drainage, so massaging and stimulating them can help the other areas drain more effectively.  MLD is light pressure, but this that I'm describing in the lower abdomen is very firm and deep.  This therapist has also suggested rolling a tennis ball deeply and repeatedly over/into that lower abdominal area since my hands tire.  At first I thought this seemed odd, but it has added one more helpful layer for me.  I have mild LE, but it's not always well controlled and seems to change for no reason.  When it flares I'm a big crab, so my family is happier the fewer flares I have.  It seems by working the lower abdominal area, my arms look smaller for awhile.  That's just been my experience so far.  I don't believe this is documented in research, so this is just personal experience.  I've had no success with insurance whatsoever, but others here have.

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2011 11:49PM kcshreve wrote: Barbe - have you had a full thyroid panel recently?  (tsh, Free T3, Free T4, TPO)  Or have you ordered a salivary corisol test? (from canaryclub.org).  These can help you determine if you have thyroid or adrenal issues.  I am just now learning about all this.  I got my thyroid taken care of about 4 years ago with a brilliant, out-of-the-box doctor after 6 consecutive docs told me my issue needed antidepressants.  The thyroid meds (both T4 and T3 products) were quite helpful.  Since my cancer surgeries, I've been extra tired and achey, and am now fairly sure there is an adrenal component.  There is a book called "Adrenal Fatigue" by James Wilson, which I'm in the middle of reading.  Very interesting and patient-friendly.  I wish you the best.  There is a wealth of info out there which our docs simply are unaware of.

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2010 11:25PM kcshreve wrote: jhwkr - I had the same symptoms as you at 3 weeks.  I had only 7 nodes removed.  I read on the lymphedema line, and I decided to find a lymphedema therapist and go talk to her, just in case there could be a connection.  I also had a swelling feeling in my right forearm, but no noticeable differece. I'm at 6 weeks now.  And while the therapist is not saying I have lymphedema, I've had her do 3 lymphatic massages and my arm is doing better. I think much of what you're experiencing is the recuperation itself, but given how many nodes were removed, it may be a good idea to do a consultation with someone certified in lymphedema therapies and discuss it with them.

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2010 10:47PM kcshreve wrote: In addition to the emotional dives we experience with a flair, it's fair to realize that dealing with a chronic condition is it's own unique challenge, since it does not have an ending date.  There are many chronic conditions, but unless you've ever dealt with one, it's just different than, say, a cold or a broken arm.  It has to be approached with a different perspective. In a non-cancer part of my life, I am involved with parents of chronically ill teens.  The parents go through a lot being caregivers in a chronic situation.  Most parents are on some kind of med support, to varying degrees- anti-depressants, benzo's like xanax or klonipin, some find they do better with thyroid support and/or adrenal supports.  Personally, I have a med I can take as needed, for which I am greatly appreciative.  That said, I still have totally crappy days regularly, since I do have a chronically ill adult child, in addition to my own stuff. At some point there is a quality of life issue which simply has to be addressed - what will it take for me to feel good today?  what will it take for me to manage well today? Regarding your pain, I recently read an article on a product which has my attention.  In the alternative/complimentary world, turmeric is very commonly used for inflammation and more and more is being associated with having anti-cancer properties.  There is a product which uses turmeric as it's base, in conjunction with a couple other herbs, which some are finding works very well for pain, as well as inflammation.  Your arthritis comment made me think of this product - arthritis and anti-cancer together - it might be an option for you. You can read up on Curcumin (turmeric), curcuminoids, and a specific product called Curamin, sold at health food stores.  I have been taking a turmeric extract since my dx, and just got a sample of this Curamin last week when I went into my local shop, but I've not used it yet.  The literature is promoting it for chronic pain issues. Just a thought.  I know neurontin works for some people, and I hope you get relief from it.  If not, there may be other options. Thinking of you, KC/Christine

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2010 01:11AM kcshreve wrote: Ninja - Regarding Kinesio taping - you can place it just about anywhere you need to move fluid.  My biggest problem area is the back of my upper arm.  The skin back there is so tender that I cannot put tape on it, but I can put tape on the outside of my upper arm and over my shoulder.  It does diminish the edema in the back of my arm.  I also run it from near my axila toward the midline of my chest to increase drainage into the lymph glands which run long that central rib area.  My LE therapist has run them everywhere, but I can only reach so many places by myself.  I also like to run them over my DIEP scars to help with the drainage there.  There are books about this, which I'm sure are quite helpful, but the design itself stimulates fluid movement, so using it anywhere is a plus, if the skin can manage it. It'sjust one more way to help.  For me, it works fairly well, but it's not remarkably amazing.  Just one more way to maintain control.

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2010 10:31PM kcshreve wrote: SleeveNinja - I can only wear my tape 3 days.  I think if I kept it on for 2 weeks my skin would come off with it.  I was told 3-5 days.  I "anchor" my tape over near the axilla - no stretch, then i very slightly give it a stretch in the middle of the strip, I end the strip near the midline, again with no stretch on the ends.  Sometimes I cut the side in the middle in half, lengthwise.  When I do this, I keep the top leg going straight across, and the bottom leg pointing down  a bit toward my cleavage.  That works the best for me.
